repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: Version numbering is handled within the DESCRIPTION file. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/blob/master/DESCRIPTION>
version_tags_justification: This package is not currently released on CRAN, and as a result, no builds have been made yet. This is planned to occur once the package achieves a stable version.
release_notes_justification: Non-trivial release notes file in repository: <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/blob/master/NEWS.md>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no publicly known vulnerabilities.
report_tracker_justification: Issues are tracked via GitHub Issues. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/issues>
report_process_justification: Bug reports can be submitted via GitHub Issues. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/issues>
report_responses_justification: All bug reports will be acknowledged in GitHub Issues. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/issues>
enhancement_responses_justification: All enhancement requests will be acknowledged in GitHub Issues. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/issues>
report_archive_justification: All reports/responses are archived in GitHub Issues. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/issues>
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: Vulnerabilities should be reported to GitHub Issues <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/issues/>
vulnerability_report_private_justificati: Private vulnerability reports should be emailed directly to the creator. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/>
build_justification: Builds are reproduced at each commit using GitHub Actions and Travis CI. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/actions>
build_common_tools_justification: Builds are reproduced at each commit using GitHub Actions and Travis CI. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/actions>
build_floss_tools_justification: Builds are reproduced at each commit using GitHub Actions and Travis CI. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/actions>
test_justification: This package uses testthat for R unit tests.
test_invocation_justification: The test suite can be invoked via devtools::test().
test_policy_justification: Informally, tests should be added for all additional functionality. It is also noted on the CONTRIBUTING page. <https://hsclientr.justinsingh.me/contributing>
tests_are_added_justification: Test coverage is tracked via CodeCov.
tests_documented_added_justification: It is, implicitly, noted on the CONTRIBUTING page. <https://hsclientr.justinsingh.me/contributing>
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: This package is using GitHub Actions and Travis CI. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/actions>
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
english_justification: Documentation is written purely in English.
documentation_quick_start_justification: This is located in the README. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR>
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio:
Contributors/Reporter(s) of vulnerabilities will be added to the DESCRIPTION file.
<https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/blob/master/DESCRIPTION>
coding_standards_justification: This package follows the tidyverse style guide. <https://hsclientr.justinsingh.me/contributing>
coding_standards_enforced_justification: This package utilizes the styler package, when necessary. <https://hsclientr.justinsingh.me/contributing>
installation_standard_variables_justific: There is no standard convention, but generally, the package will be installed into the user's personal library.
installation_development_quick_justifica: This is done via the common git fork/pr workflow in conjunction with the devtools package in R.
external_dependencies_justification: External dependencies are listed in the DESCRIPTION file. <https://github.com/program--/HSClientR/blob/master/DESCRIPTION>
dependency_monitoring_justification: This package only uses the latest version of its external dependencies.
updateable_reused_components_justificati: Functions within the package are segmented and re-used often.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: testthat is run each time a commit is pushed, as well as reported to codecov.io after.

name: ScorpioBroker
description: NGSI-LD compliant context broker named Scorpio. Developed by NEC Laboratories Europe and NEC Technologies India
description_good_justification: The project has a well formed readme describing architecture, functionality and usage of the software
interact_justification: Contribution guidelines are provided https://github.com/ScorpioBroker/ScorpioBroker/blob/development/CONTRIBUTING.md. Feedback mail provided. Bug reporting via Github is used.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/ScorpioBroker/ScorpioBroker/blob/development/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/ScorpioBroker/ScorpioBroker/blob/development/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The BSD-3-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The BSD-3-Clause license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification: Some documentation basics file contents found.
documentation_interface_justification:
Full documentation provided on read the docs. https://scorpio.readthedocs.io/en/latest/ 
API spec referenced on Github readme to the implemented NGSI-LD API specification.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: The project has multiple members. No direct contribution to the development and the master branch shall be done. https://scorpio.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributionGuideline.html. Pull request require 2 reviews from project members. Major releases are tagged with FIWARE_<FIWARE release number> in accordance with the FIWARE guidelines we have to follow. Interim releases are numbered by x.x.x format and package multiple PRs normally.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: The project is using SemVer for versioning. Some releases are double versioned as FIWARE_<FIWARE release> since this is required by the FIWARE consortium we are part of https://www.fiware.org/.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no publicly known vulnerabilities
report_responses_justification: https://github.com/ScorpioBroker/ScorpioBroker/issues Issues are replied to within a week normally.
enhancement_responses_justification:
https://github.com/ScorpioBroker/ScorpioBroker/issues 
All request are replied within a week normally. New feature requests are always considered and discussed.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Active support. No external vulnerability reports yet.
build_floss_tools_justification: OpenJDK based. Maven is the only requirement to build the project.
test_justification: The project has it's own unit tests using JUnit. Additionally system tests are done using the FIWARE NGSI-LD Test Suite https://github.com/FIWARE/NGSI-LD_TestSuite. It's automated via github actions CI https://github.com/ScorpioBroker/ScorpioBroker/actions
test_invocation_justification: JUnit is standard for Java. The NGSI-LD test suite is maintained externally and well documented for use.
test_policy_justification: New major functionality is coming from spec updates of NGSI-LD and will be cover in the corresponding test suite provided by ETSI, which is used for testing.
tests_documented_added_justification: The new function must pass the integrated test and will be documented in the release notes
warnings_justification: Java compiler warnings are addressed in code if they are intentionally ignored. Further compiler warnings are addressed and will be checked on PR.
warnings_fixed_justification: Warnings are either directly addressed or intentionally ignored via annotations where needed. E.g. external libs doesn't use generics so we are ignoring rawtype warnings for interactions here. or certain unchecked casts are not really unchecked.
warnings_strict_justification: Java compiler has warnings on by default. Warnings are addressed.
know_secure_design_justification: The Scorpio development team has developers who know how to design secure software
know_common_errors_justification: The Scorpio development team has developers who know how to design secure software
crypto_published_justification:
The project is build using Spring Cloud and components provided by it. https://spring.io/projects/spring-cloud
Apache Tomcat is used as webserver and HTTPS encryption is handled by it. OAuth integration is handled via spring components.
crypto_call_justification: Standard Spring Cloud components are used for HTTPS. No own implementation for cryptography.
crypto_floss_justification:
Standard Spring Cloud components are used for HTTPS. No own implementation for cryptography. Spring components are released under Apache License 
https://spring.io
crypto_keylength_justification: Cryptographic libraries used by Scorpio Broker and/or the OAuth integration via Spring and an OAuth server to which it interacts (Keyrock or Keystone tested) allow the usage of such minimum key lengths.
crypto_working_justification: Scorpio Broker doesn’t use any broken cryptographic algorithm.
crypto_pfs_justification: Nothing in the code inhibits or prevents the use of PFS; that is a property of the website's web server.
crypto_random_justification: Cryptographic libraries used by Scorpio Broker and/or the other microservices to which it interacts (Keyrock or Keystone) use randomized mechanisms.
delivery_unsigned_justification: Scorpio Broker does not cryptographic hashes in any HTTP unsecure endpoint.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: No such vulnerabilities at this time. Dependobot PRs and issues are addressed within max 60 days
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: No such vulnerabilities at this time. Dependobot PRs and issues are addressed within max 60 days
static_analysis_justification: PMD is used for code analysis and is triggered as github action workflow
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Dependobot is used to find vulnerabilities in libraries and PMD for the code
static_analysis_fixed_justification: Vulnerabilities are fixed within a timely manner.
static_analysis_often_justification: Github action for PMD takes care of code analysis on every push
crypto_weaknesses_justification: Scorpio Broker doesn’t depend on cryptographic algorithms with known vulnerabilities.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Scorpio Broker has a default password for the database configuration and has documented how to change it.
english_justification: Active support on Github issues is provided in English. Except for one Japanese translation all documentation is provided in English
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.
maintained_justification: Actively maintained regular PRs and issue discussions

name: Powsybl
description: PowSyBl (Power System Blocks) is an open source library written in Java, dedicated to electrical grid modelling and simulation. The power system blocks may be used through scripts for a quick shot, but also be assembled to build state of the art applications.
description_good_justification:
https://www.powsybl.org/
The web site provides an over view of the project, with the license, the governance and the roadmap, a documentation user oriented and developer oriented and a clear explanation of how to contribute.
contribution_justification: https://www.powsybl.org/pages/contributing/ via pull requests on the different repositories.
contribution_requirements_justification:
https://www.powsybl.org/pages/contributing/
The styleguides are more detailed here: https://github.com/powsybl/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#styleguides
license_location_justification: https://www.powsybl.org/pages/overview/license
floss_license_justification: https://github.com/gridsuite The MPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The MPL-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
https://www.powsybl.org/pages/documentation/index.html#user-documentation
Javadoc: https://javadoc.io/doc/com.powsybl/powsybl-core/latest/index.html
repo_public_justification: https://github.com/powsybl/powsybl-core for the main and historical repository.
repo_track_justification: https://github.com/powsybl/powsybl-core/commits/master for all commits and associated pull requests.
repo_interim_justification: Powsybl community provides release candidates for its main repository powsybl-core. For example: https://javadoc.io/doc/com.powsybl/powsybl-core/4.0.0-RC2/index.html
repo_distributed_justification: We use git.
release_notes_vulns_justification: There have been no publicly known security vulnerabilities in the project itself, not its dependencies, that why we choose to answer N/A.
report_tracker_justification:
https://github.com/powsybl/powsybl-core/projects
We use github projects for that.
report_responses_justification: As we report bugs and evolutions in the same way, all issues are not resolved in that delay. But we use the label "bug" and then "bug fix" for bugs and the resolution time matchs with this delay.
enhancement_responses_justification: The complete review process takes between one day to 2 months maximum. The other pull requests, open since a long time should be closed because abandoned or closed and put again in the roadmap because postponed.
report_archive_justification:
https://github.com/powsybl/powsybl-core/pulls
We also have a Spectrum and a mailing list https://lists.lfenergy.org/g/powsybl-dev
vulnerability_report_process_justificati: The same way as bug reporting, see https://www.powsybl.org/pages/contributing/
build_justification: We rely on github actions for the CI. We don't have any CD as Powsybl is a dependancy for softwares, not a software itself.
build_common_tools_justification: We use github actions for our CI on Linux, MacOS and Windows.
test_justification: We have unit tests required before merging pull request on main branch (80% of test coverage).
test_invocation_justification:
To run unit-test for java modules, you can use the "mvn test" command or your IDE. For C++ modules, you have to run "make tests"
TODO: update the README to explain how to run the tests
test_policy_justification: Its is required before merging a branch on main branch.
warnings_justification: We use Sonarcloud to report bugs, style and code duplication. We also use linters (checkstyle, clang-tidy) for common mistakes.
warnings_strict_justification: Sonar gives for each pull request a feedback about smells. The reviewer is in responsible for asking contributor to fix relevant issues and accept non relevant warnings. Compilation warnings displayed in the logs during compilation are failed during the development phase
delivery_mitm_justification: HTTPS is used between our micro services.
vulnerabilities_fixed_60_days_justificat: There have been no publicly known security vulnerabilities in the project itself.
vulnerabilities_critical_fixed_justifica: There have been no publicly known security vulnerabilities in the project itself.
static_analysis_justification: Sonarcloud is used and in the contributing, we encourage developers to use IntelliJ IDE.
static_analysis_fixed_justification: It is required before merging pull request on main branch.
dynamic_analysis_justification: We have unit tests, a test coverage computation and memory leak detection.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification: We use Valgrind for the C++ analysis code, but it is not automatic. I am going to write an issue on Github.
discussion_justification:
https://www.powsybl.org/pages/community/
Official canal: https://spectrum.chat/powsybl?tab=posts
that would be moved to Slack: https://app.slack.com/client/TG8ALA0TB
no_leaked_credentials_justification: Our .jars, distributed on Maven Central, are signed.
english_justification: The web site is in English. Issues and pull requests are in English. The code is also fully is English.
hardening_justification: In our C++ code, we can start by using compiler flags. What do you suggest for Java code?
dco_justification:
https://probot.github.io/apps/dco/
We use DCO and it is mandatory in our CI to pass.
roles_responsibilities_justification:
https://www.powsybl.org/pages/documentation/developer/repositories/
The responsibilities by repository are detailed in that page. Each repository has its own page, for example for powsybl-core: https://www.powsybl.org/pages/documentation/developer/repositories/powsybl-core.html
access_continuity_justification: https://www.powsybl.org/pages/documentation/developer/repositories/ for each repository, the responsibilities are always shared by two people.
bus_factor_justification:
https://github.com/powsybl/powsybl-core/
TF = 4 (coverage = 41.00%)
TF authors (Developer;Files;Percentage):
Geoffroy Jamgotchian;863;28.62
Mathieu BAGUE;843;27.96
MioRtia;583;19.34
Luma;313;10.38
documentation_architecture_justification: Powsybl is a library that provides power system blocks used by softwares but does not have an adherence to a dedicated architecture.
documentation_quick_start_justification:
We have a getting started: 
We provide some tutorials: https://www.powsybl.org/pages/documentation/developer/tutorials/
documentation_current_justification: The web site documentation is updated at each release.
accessibility_best_practices_justificati: Powsybl code and documentation is in english. There is no GUI over Powsybl.
internationalization_justification: Powsybl code and documentation is in english (only).
maintenance_or_update_justification: In our migration guides. For example, for last release: https://github.com/powsybl/powsybl-core/wiki/Migration-guide-v4.1.0
coding_standards_justification:
https://github.com/powsybl/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#styleguides
CI : we use linters and coding style checkers.
coding_standards_enforced_justification: Developers are expected to follow the project guidelines (we use standard coding styles). The coding style is checked during compilation.
build_standard_variables_justification: The C++ libraries we develop use CMake that allows to pass additional flags to the compilers and linkers using standard CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS and CMAKE_LD_FLAGS variables.
build_preserve_debug_justification: If the build type is set to Debug during project configuration phase, additional flags are passed to the compiler to add Debug information.
installation_standard_variables_justific: The installation system is standard, the installation location is configurable if needed.
external_dependencies_justification:
Dependencies are listed in the pom.xml files or in the CMakeLists.txt files.
https://github.com/powsybl/powsybl-core/blob/master/pom.xml
https://github.com/powsybl/powsybl-iidm4cpp/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt
dependency_monitoring_justification: Github provides a bot that detects vulnerabilities and opens pull requests to fix dependency versions. We also checked for dependency updates when new Powsybl releases are published.
updateable_reused_components_justificati:
For Java modules, the version of external dependencies are listed at the beginning of the parent pom.xml that makes it easy to update one or several dependencies.
For C++ modules, we use system dependencies that should be up-to-date, but allow the users to use a custom version by updating the dependencies home directories.
interfaces_current_justification: When some functions are marked deprecated, we adapt the existing code following migration guides provided by the projects. We also pay really attention when we choose to add a new dependency to the project to select active and well maintained projects. If a project is not maintained anymore or seems to be inactive, we try to find an alternative project that fulfill our needs.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: Unit tests have been implemented using Junit and are automatically run during the CI. If tests failed, the merge of the pull request is blocked until they pass. The report is produced by Jacoco.
regression_tests_added50_justification: When we met a bug, we create a unit test to reproduce it (TDD).
test_policy_mandated_justification: When a new functionality is introduced in Powsybl, the CI ensure that the code coverage remains at least the same, and the new code is well tested. If those requirements are not filled, the PR is blocked.
implement_secure_design_justification: Our project is not producing software but a framework dedicated to be integrated in a whole application that is responsible for the security assessment described in this requirement.
signed_releases_justification: Our modules are released on maven central that requires each files to be signed, and the public key available on a key server (pool.sks-keyservers.net).
version_tags_signed_justification: Currently, version tag are done by TSC members. We didn't require that they add their GPG key to their GitHub account, but will ask for it from the next release.
small_tasks_justification:
We use a github label "good first issue" to identify small tasks.
https://github.com/powsybl/powsybl-core/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3A%22good+first+issue%22
two_person_review_justification: All the PR are reviewed entirely and for powsybl-core most of the time two reviewers are required.

name: FogFlow
description: FogFlow is a standard-based IoT fog computing framework that supports serverless computing and edge computing with advanced programming models. It automatically orchestrates dynamic data processing flows over cloud and edges based on various context, including: 1) system context: the available system resources from all layers; 2) data context: the registered metadata of all available data entities; 3) usage context: the expected usage intention defined by users in terms QoS, latency, and bandwidth cost. Thanks to its advanced intent-based programming model and context-driven service orchestration, FogFlow is able to provide optimized QoS with minimal development effort and nearly zero operation overhead. Currently, FogFlow has been applied into various business use cases in the areas of retails, smart cities, and smart industry.
sites_https_justification: the detailed setup instruction to support HTTPs is provided under https://fogflow.readthedocs.io/en/latest/https.html
